meanings.definition: To prolong or extend in time or space.
meanings.sent1: She decided to protract the meeting by discussing irrelevant topics.
meanings.sent2: The construction project was protracted due to unexpected delays.
meanings.sent3: The teacher tried to protract the class by telling jokes, but the students were not amused.
meanings.sent4: The endless wait at the airport seemed to protract time itself.
meanings.sent5: His decision to protract the decision-making process only led to more confusion.

meanings.definition: To draw out or lengthen in time or space.
meanings.sent1: The magician used a trick to protract the illusion and amaze the audience.
meanings.sent2: The negotiations were protracted as both parties struggled to reach a compromise.
meanings.sent3: The cat tried to protract the game of chase by hiding behind the curtains.
meanings.sent4: Her words seemed to protract into infinity, echoing in the empty room.
meanings.sent5: The artist's brush strokes protracted the lines of the landscape, creating a sense of depth.
